description: MTA Overview The Microsoft Technology Associate (MTA) IT Infrastructure is designed to be an entry level certification for people getting started in the IT career field. The Windows Operating System Fundamentals exam covers general topics related to the day-to-day operation of a Windows 7 workstation and some of the administrative tasks required to keep the machine running smoothly. Upon completing the 98-349 exam, you will be awarded the MTA IT Infrastructure certification which demonstrates to employers that you have the basic skills required to provide IT support in a help desk or field technician role.
name: MTA - Windows Operating System Fundamentals -  98-349
subtitle: Windows Operating System Fundamentals

episodes.description: In this episode Don and Ronnie give an overview of the MTA certification. This overview helps us understand who this certification is intended for and how much experience the ideal candidate is expected to have.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes discuss and demonstrate some of the key mobility settings you can find when Windows is running on a mobile platform such as a laptop.  These features help with extending battery life and staying connected to resources such as other computers and even files when there is no connection to the network, according to the team.  They demonstrate the use of Remote Desktop Connection, using the Mobility Center and how to Synchronize files when the mobile device and network resource is connected back to the network.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Don talk about multiple considerations IT professionals need to consider when installing the Windows 7 operating system. 00:32:22.640 --> 00:32:24.651

00:32:24.651 --> 00:32:25.981
We're gonna choose Edit.

595
00:32:28.620 --> 00:32:32.312
And we're gonna add the Read & execute.

00:32:32.312 --> 00:32:34.928

Modify as well there,

597
00:32:34.928 --> 00:32:37.558
the permissions that we
were talking about earlier.

598
00:32:37.558 --> 00:32:39.474
But this should give
you a pretty good idea.

599
00:32:39.474 --> 00:32:41.394

600
00:32:41.394 --> 00:32:45.750
This should give you a pretty good idea on
how you can control access to files and

00:32:45.750 --> 00:32:48.130

602

Let me go ahead and logon as User01 now.

00:32:53.044 --> 00:32:56.708
And the goal on this is to see if we

00:32:56.708 --> 00:32:59.411

605
00:32:59.411 --> 00:33:05.028

606
00:33:05.028 --> 00:33:06.897

607
00:33:06.897 --> 00:33:09.857

608
00:33:09.857 --> 00:33:13.360

the level of access that we want.

609
00:33:13.360 --> 00:33:16.390
We're controlling access to files and
folders.

610
00:33:16.390 --> 00:33:20.110
Now, why is it that these

611
00:33:20.110 --> 00:33:24.425
The last thing I wanna mention here is
something known as permission inheritance,

612
00:33:24.425 --> 00:33:24.943
okay?

00:33:24.943 --> 00:33:31.470

614
00:33:31.470 --> 00:33:33.470
Understand that when you have a folder,

615
00:33:33.470 --> 00:33:36.550
there's a special relationship
to a folder and a file.

616
00:33:36.550 --> 00:33:39.795
If I put a file in a folder
that has permissions set on it,

617
00:33:39.795 --> 00:33:42.499
it automatically inherits the permissions.

618
00:33:42.499 --> 00:33:46.414
That's why I can see that if I look, for

instance, let me go ahead and
look at Putty here.

620

622
00:34:00.080 --> 00:34:02.080

623
00:34:02.080 --> 00:34:03.610

624
00:34:03.610 --> 00:34:08.090
They're being inherited
from their parent object.

625
00:34:08.090 --> 00:34:10.910
Now that is a very easy way
to manage your permissions.

626
00:34:10.910 --> 00:34:12.439

627
00:34:12.439 --> 00:34:16.401

628
00:34:16.401 --> 00:34:21.484
I could set it one time at the folder
level, dump all of those files in there,

629
00:34:21.484 --> 00:34:26.191
and now they all inherit down,
making it easier to do access control.

630
00:34:26.191 --> 00:34:29.468
Now, that essentially is what

631
00:34:29.468 --> 00:34:33.858
As you've seen, permissions allow us
the ability to control who has access.

632
00:34:33.858 --> 00:34:39.020

access that they have to the documents and

633

634
00:34:41.103 --> 00:34:45.119

637

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take a look at setting up share permissions.  They begin with configuring file and printer sharing on the resource machine to allow for access.  Also, they show how to connect to the resource computer using the UNC path and mapping a network drive.  They also discuss the use of share permissions to grant access to the network resource.  The emphasize when connecting from a remote computer to the network resource, the most restrictive of the NTFS Permissions and Share permissions apply.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes take a look at supporting printers in Windows 10. 1407

1409
01:06:50,282 --> 01:06:54,080
All right, so

1410
01:06:54,080 --> 01:06:59,088
There is an extra layer for those of you
that move on to do the MCSA certification,

1411
01:06:59,088 --> 01:07:03,434
in a business environment you can
set up what's called a WSUS server,

1412
01:07:03,434 --> 01:07:06,180
a Windows Server Update Service.

1413
01:07:06,180 --> 01:07:12,030
And what it does is it lets you basically
have your own Windows update server.

1414
01:07:12,030 --> 01:07:14,140
So right here I'm reaching
out to Microsoft and

1415
01:07:14,140 --> 01:07:17,110
they're telling me just the updates
that are available, but

1416
01:07:17,110 --> 01:07:20,450
with a WSUS server you have
your own Windows update server.

1417
01:07:20,450 --> 01:07:24,141
It reaches out to Microsoft and gets the
updates, but then you're able to pick and

1418
01:07:24,141 --> 01:07:25,972
choose which ones are allowed to apply.

1419
01:07:25,972 --> 01:07:30,310
Sometimes an update can break
your business software.

1420
01:07:30,310 --> 01:07:33,600
For example, if a new version
of Internet Explorer comes out

1421
01:07:33,600 --> 01:07:34,460
you might not be ready for that.

1422
01:07:34,460 --> 01:07:36,520
Your software might not support it yet.

1423
01:07:36,520 --> 01:07:40,125
So in WSUS you can turn
turn off certain updates,

1424
01:07:40,125 --> 01:07:41,965
like that new version
of Internet Explorer.

1425
01:07:41,965 --> 01:07:44,625
You still need to do
your security updates.

1426
01:07:44,625 --> 01:07:48,835
But maybe I stay on IE 10 and
I don't go to IE 11 right away.

1427
01:07:48,835 --> 01:07:50,425
IE 10 still gets security updates.

1428
01:07:50,425 --> 01:07:51,620
It's still supported.

1429
01:07:51,620 --> 01:07:55,850
So as long as you stay on supported
software it'll work out just fine.

1430
01:07:55,850 --> 01:07:58,590
Now if you're saying I need to
stay on Internet Explorer 6,

1431
01:07:58,590 --> 01:08:03,080
that's not supported by Microsoft anymore
and it's not supported by WSUS either.

1432
01:08:03,080 --> 01:08:06,910
It's not gonna pull any updates for
it and you're gonna be out of support.

1433
01:08:06,910 --> 01:08:09,220
That's definitely not
a situation you wanna be in.

1434
01:08:09,220 --> 01:08:12,250
So you never wanna stay on old,
unsupported software.

1435
01:08:12,250 --> 01:08:15,560

by Microsoft, they'll continue to release

1436
01:08:15,560 --> 01:08:18,960

1437
01:08:18,960 --> 01:08:22,880
So just be aware of that as you move
into like, a business environment,

1438
01:08:22,880 --> 01:08:24,010

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore the importance of backups, recovery, and updates in Windows 10. They start by taking you through the necessary steps to perform a System Restore, create a Recovery Drive, and boot into Safe Mode, exploring the details of when/why each are utilized.
episodes.title: Backup, Recovery and Updates
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.341
Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.341 --> 00:00:08.244
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.244 --> 00:00:12.144
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.144 --> 00:00:14.068
>> All right, greetings everyone and

5
00:00:14.068 --> 00:00:16.706
welcome to another great
episode of ITPRO.TV.

6
00:00:16.706 --> 00:00:21.696
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode we're back with more of our MTA

7
00:00:21.696 --> 00:00:24.850
series, our good old 98-349 specifically.

8
00:00:24.850 --> 00:00:28.640
And joining us in the studio again today,
our good friend Mr. Wes Bryant.

9
00:00:28.640 --> 00:00:30.055
Wes, glad to have you back my man,
how's it going out there?

10
00:00:30.055 --> 00:00:33.472
>> Well man its going great, props to
you for remembering those exam codes,

11
00:00:33.472 --> 00:00:35.632
boy they're an acronym in and
of themselves.

12
00:00:35.632 --> 00:00:40.060
And that's right, we're here to
actually wrap up our MTA series.

13
00:00:40.060 --> 00:00:44.110
And one of the last things that
we are gonna discuss are about

14
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:47.870
maintaining the availability
of your machines.

15
00:00:47.870 --> 00:00:53.570
And we do that typically through backup
of our machines, recovery of our machines

16
00:00:53.570 --> 00:00:57.470
as well as just general maintenance
through things like your Windows updates.

17
00:00:57.470 --> 00:01:01.490
So we're gonna talk about some of
those concepts here in this episode.

18
00:01:01.490 --> 00:01:04.452
One of the very first ones that we're
gonna dive into is an oldie but goodie,

19
00:01:04.452 --> 00:01:06.232
one that's been around Windows for awhile.

20
00:01:06.232 --> 00:01:10.754
And it's one that we use when
we have maybe problematic

21
00:01:10.754 --> 00:01:13.318
symptoms within our systems.

22
00:01:13.318 --> 00:01:17.466
We look at, for instance, if we install
applications and they cause problems or

23
00:01:17.466 --> 00:01:19.960
if we install drivers they cause problems.

24
00:01:19.960 --> 00:01:24.600
Wouldn't it be nice to be able to restore
your computer to a its configuration

25
00:01:24.600 --> 00:01:26.140
state to an earlier point in time.

26
00:01:26.140 --> 00:01:29.127
And that's the piece of software
known as system restore.

27
00:01:29.127 --> 00:01:31.846
Now again this is not new
technology to windows so

28
00:01:31.846 --> 00:01:36.507
if you've have been in Windows 7, if
you've been in, actually going back to XP.

29
00:01:36.507 --> 00:01:39.611
If you've been in Windows XP,
Windows 7, 8, 8.1 and

30
00:01:39.611 --> 00:01:43.338
now the flagship client operating
system for Windows, Windows 10,

31
00:01:43.338 --> 00:01:46.090
then you're probably
already familiar with this.

32
00:01:46.090 --> 00:01:49.520
However, if this is the first time
you've ever heard about system restore,

33
00:01:49.520 --> 00:01:52.420
it's really gonna be
important to understand it.

34
00:01:52.420 --> 00:01:56.330
Not only from an exam perspective, but
really to take it for a test drive, kind

35
00:01:56.330 --> 00:02:00.310
of see what it does, so that if you have
to support end users in your environment,

36
00:02:00.310 --> 00:02:03.040
you will know one of the utilities
that's really baked into Windows,

37
00:02:03.040 --> 00:02:06.920
that it doesn't require going to a third
party to get this functionality.

38
00:02:06.920 --> 00:02:08.420
Let's go and dive right in here.

39
00:02:08.420 --> 00:02:13.270
I've got a Windows 10 machine and what
we're gonna do is we're gonna show you how

40
00:02:13.270 --> 00:02:16.650
to ensure that system restore is enabled,

41
00:02:16.650 --> 00:02:20.040
that it is turned on and
ready to protect our systems.

42
00:02:20.040 --> 00:02:20.900
So let's go ahead, and

43
00:02:20.900 --> 00:02:23.190
what we're gonna do is we're gonna
go to our system properties.

44
00:02:23.190 --> 00:02:25.890
And there's a few different ways that
you can get to your system properties.

45
00:02:25.890 --> 00:02:30.550
You can always right-click on your little
Windows icon down here in the Start menu

46
00:02:30.550 --> 00:02:32.630
or the task bar, excuse me.

47
00:02:32.630 --> 00:02:36.060
And from here we can just
choose if we want System.

48
00:02:36.060 --> 00:02:40.740
Another way that you can do this too
is if you open File Explorer and

49
00:02:40.740 --> 00:02:43.760
there is,
over here on the left hand side, This PC.

50
00:02:43.760 --> 00:02:48.180
And if I was to right-click,
I could scroll down and

51
00:02:48.180 --> 00:02:53.070
we could choose, for instance, if I
can get there without it disappearing,

52
00:02:53.070 --> 00:02:54.270
we can choose Properties here.

53
00:02:54.270 --> 00:02:58.280
So either way will take you
to the system control panel.

54
00:02:58.280 --> 00:03:01.420
You can also go via Control Panel too.

55
00:03:01.420 --> 00:03:05.320
So if we open up our Control Panel
we can go to System and Security and

56
00:03:05.320 --> 00:03:06.330
we can go to system.

57
00:03:06.330 --> 00:03:11.100
So you can see few different ways
to get to the same location.

58
00:03:11.100 --> 00:03:16.790
And I can tell you if this first time you
maybe are endeavoring in a Microsoft exam,

59
00:03:16.790 --> 00:03:19.860
understand that you don't know
which way they're gonna ask you.

60
00:03:19.860 --> 00:03:23.280
So, really get familiar with
the operating system and

61
00:03:23.280 --> 00:03:25.560
know multiple ways to get
to different locations.

62
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:27.860
So with that being said, let's go ahead.

63
00:03:27.860 --> 00:03:31.000
We're going to use our task link and
we're going to use this option right here.

64
00:03:31.000 --> 00:03:34.270
We're going to click this little
system protection task link.

65
00:03:34.270 --> 00:03:37.230
It does bring you into
the system properties.

66
00:03:37.230 --> 00:03:41.350
I do want you to keep in mind though, that
pretty much except for Device Manager,

67
00:03:41.350 --> 00:03:45.370
every one one of these links will take
you to the traditional system properties.

68
00:03:45.370 --> 00:03:50.190
So if I hit advanced system settings,
you can see it's still system properties,

69
00:03:50.190 --> 00:03:52.070
it's just what tab is the focus.

70
00:03:52.070 --> 00:03:55.710
In this case I want the focus
to be the System Protection tab.

71
00:03:55.710 --> 00:03:59.100
Now one of the things that you're probably
gonna see right away is the protection

72
00:03:59.100 --> 00:03:59.620
settings.

73
00:03:59.620 --> 00:04:02.740
And I can see Local Disk (C:),
this is our root drive.

74
00:04:02.740 --> 00:04:04.860
And I can see the protection
is turned off.

75
00:04:04.860 --> 00:04:08.780
Well, that's a bad thing because one of
the things you'll also notice is that that

76
00:04:08.780 --> 00:04:11.900
disables here our System Restore.

77
00:04:11.900 --> 00:04:16.030
And that's certainly not gonna help
us if we need to use system restore.

78
00:04:16.030 --> 00:04:16.860
So let's go ahead and

79
00:04:16.860 --> 00:04:21.030
start this by getting it configured
to use our system restore utility.

80
00:04:21.030 --> 00:04:22.740
We're gonna go ahead and choose configure.

81
00:04:22.740 --> 00:04:26.940
>> Wes, really quickly, why is it that
they disable this by default, why so?

82
00:04:26.940 --> 00:04:29.890
You would think this is something
that would have enabled by default?

83
00:04:29.890 --> 00:04:34.920
>> I'm honestly not sure why,
one of the reasons I would guess, and

84
00:04:34.920 --> 00:04:38.130
again this speculation here, is they've
got a lot of other things today that

85
00:04:38.130 --> 00:04:42.708
we can use that, the system restore
has been around for a while.

86
00:04:42.708 --> 00:04:45.250
Now, they have new technologies out,
like a system reset and

87
00:04:45.250 --> 00:04:49.060
PC refreshes,
that can basically reinstall Window's,

88
00:04:49.060 --> 00:04:53.330
keep your files in place, or
completely eliminate your files.

89
00:04:53.330 --> 00:04:57.370
However, that's a little intrusive,
right, maybe we just need to restore our

90
00:04:57.370 --> 00:04:59.810
configuration files and
that's where system restore is.

91
00:04:59.810 --> 00:05:02.870
So one of the things I would say is it's
probably disabled because of the other

92
00:05:02.870 --> 00:05:04.580
technologies they have.

93
00:05:04.580 --> 00:05:08.211
However, I like to turn it on and
use it because it's the least, for

94
00:05:08.211 --> 00:05:12.805
me it's one of the least intrusive methods
to troubleshooting a system and hopefully

95
00:05:12.805 --> 00:05:17.182
bringing it back online if you get this
intermittent activity or problems here.

96
00:05:17.182 --> 00:05:20.160
So once we've gone in here
to system protection for

97
00:05:20.160 --> 00:05:25.089
the disk, we're gonna go ahead and we're
gonna choose turn on system protection.

98
00:05:25.089 --> 00:05:29.340
We also have a certain
amount of disk usage.

99
00:05:29.340 --> 00:05:33.849
Keep in mind that it is very very low
at first and that's because we can take

100
00:05:33.849 --> 00:05:37.362
this all the way up to 13 gigs and
even beyond if we want.

101
00:05:37.362 --> 00:05:39.858
But keep in mind that when you do that,

102
00:05:39.858 --> 00:05:43.374
you run the risk of accruing
a lot of Hard Drive space.

103
00:05:43.374 --> 00:05:48.056
And anytime you start accruing storage and
the capacity starts to grow,

104
00:05:48.056 --> 00:05:53.199
you could potentially see problems even
though drive sizes today, for the most

105
00:05:53.199 --> 00:05:58.320
part, we don't really have to worry
